source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: Pressure tubes that form the primary pressure boundary in CANDU reactors are made of cold worked Zr-2.5Nb autoclaved in steam at 400°C to produce a black adherent oxide film of ~1 to 2 μm in thickness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: Trace elements in Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube material are generally low (<50 ppm) with the exception of iron (<500 ppm w/w) and (~1000 ppm w/w).
composition_raw: Trace elements generally low (<50 ppm); iron (<500 ppm w/w); unspecified element (~1000 ppm w/w)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: Trace elements in Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube material are generally low (<50 ppm) with the exception of iron (<500 ppm w/w) and (~1000 ppm w/w).
composition_raw: Trace elements generally low (<50 ppm); iron (<500 ppm w/w); unspecified element (~1000 ppm w/w)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: Average deuterium uptake rates in Ontario Hydro's pressure tubes are generally low (<1 ppm by weight/annum)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: On pressure tube inside surfaces, which are in contact with lithiated heavy water (D₂O) coolant at 250 to 300°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: On pressure tube inside surfaces, which are in contact with lithiated heavy water (D₂O) coolant at 250 to 300°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: Average uniform oxide thicknesses on pressure tube inside surfaces have not exceeded ~20 μm after 4350 effective full power days (EFPD).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: The oxides on the outer surfaces of the pressure tubes are in contact with a generally dry (typically -20 to -50°C dew point) annulus gas consisting of nitrogen (N₂) or carbon dioxide (CO₂) with <25 ppm oxygen (O₂) and up to 1 vol% deuterium, at approximately atmospheric pressure.

conditions.atmosphere: dry (dew point -20 to -50°C); nitrogen (N₂) or carbon dioxide (CO₂); <25 ppm oxygen (O₂); up to 1 vol% deuterium

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: Thin rectangular specimens were cut from the inside and outside surfaces of irradiated pressure tubes at selected axial locations corresponding to different average rates of hydrogen ingress and local reactor environments, following 2800 to 4350 EFPD exposure in-reactor.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk1
evidence_span: Thermal-hydraulic modeling calculations show that the 6 o'clock location may be up to 15°C hotter than the 12 o'clock location for the same axial location.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens exposed out-of-reactor to controlled deuterium gas environment were also taken from coupons of $\mathsf { Z r } { \mathsf { - } } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ pressure tube material and high purity $( 9 9 . 9 9 \% )$ crystal bar zirconium following aqueous/steam oxidation in autoclaves at temperatures of 300 to $4 0 0 \mathrm { { \circ } C }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: Selected specimens were then exposed to vacuum $\mathit { \Omega } \cdot \mathit { 1 0 ^ { - 8 } }$ torr $[ 1 . 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { P a } ] ,$ at temperatures of 400 to $5 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ in order to investigate possible changes occurring in the oxide in a simulated reducing reactor annulus gas environment.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: This tube had low bulk alloy deuterium concentrations along its length $( < 1 0 ~ \mathrm { p p m ~ w / w ~ D } )$ , following 2800 EFPD exposure to a $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ annulus gas.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: Higher deuterium contents are found in the oxides of specimens taken from the hotter 6 o'clock location compared to specimens removed from the 12 o'clock position.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: In this pressure tube, as in others where deuterium concentrations in the bulk alloy are low $( < 1 0 \mathrm { \ p p m \ w / w } )$ , the deuterium content in the oxide consistently drops sharply by up to three orders of magnitude before the oxide/metal interface is reached.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: In Fig. 1, the solid line represents the best-fit deuterium concentration profile calculated using this approach with a diffusion coefficient of $2 \times 1 0 ^ { - 2 2 } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { s }$ at $3 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: Also shown in this figure is the deuterium concentration profile calculated assuming a value of $_ \mathrm { D }$ of $2 ~ \times$ $1 0 ^ { - 2 1 } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { s }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: In Figs. 2 and 4, the deuterium concentrations appear to be increasing in the outer 100 to $2 0 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ of oxide.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: Thus the inner oxide layer next to the metal-oxide interface provides maximum resistance to the diffusion of deuterium. The outer oxide layer, up to $- 1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ from the oxide surface, offers less resistance to deuterium diffusion.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens of $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ prefilmed in steam for 24 h at $4 0 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ (oxide thickness ${ \sim } 1 ~ { \mu } \mathrm { m }$ ), and exposed to pure deuterium $\mathrm { 1 0 0 ~ k P a }$ , $3 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ ,9 days) in all cases showed deuterium concentration profiles that appeared to be diffusion limited; a typical example is seen in Fig. 3a.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens of $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ prefilmed in steam for 24 h at $4 0 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ (oxide thickness ${ \sim } 1 ~ { \mu } \mathrm { m }$ ), and exposed to pure deuterium $\mathrm { 1 0 0 ~ k P a }$ , $3 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ ,9 days) in all cases showed deuterium concentration profiles that appeared to be diffusion limited; a typical example is seen in Fig. 3a.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: Steam prefilmed specimens that had been exposed to vacuum $[ 1 0 ^ { - 1 0 }$ torr $[ 1 . 3 ~ \times ~ 1 0 ^ { - 8 }$ Pa]) at $4 5 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ for 3 days, showed similar concentration profiles after exposure to deuterium gas as shown in Fig. $_ { 3 b }$ . Best-fit deuterium concentration profiles are also shown in this figure, where diffusion coefficients are found to be a factor of ${ \sim } 2 0$ times higher

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: diffusion coefficients are found to be a factor of ${ \sim } 2 0$ times higher, apparently because of the degradation of the oxide during vacuum annealing.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: Thus vacuum degradation appears to reduce the efficacy of the oxide as a hydrogen permeation barrier.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: A specimen of pure zirconium in the steam-prefilmed condition was also exposed to high purity $\cdot { < } 1$ ppm impurities including $\mathrm { O } _ { 2 }$ deuterium gas at $1 0 0 \ \mathbf { k P a }$ , at $3 0 0 \mathrm { { ^ \circ C } }$ for 7 days.

conditions.atmosphere: high purity $\cdot { < } 1$ ppm impurities including $\mathrm { O } _ { 2 }$ deuterium gas

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: Because of higher oxidation rates of this material, oxide thicknesses for comparable exposure conditions were 2 to 3 times greater than the thickness observed for $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ pressure tube material.

conditions.atmosphere: high purity $\cdot { < } 1$ ppm impurities including $\mathrm { O } _ { 2 }$ deuterium gas

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: This oxide showed higher deuterium concentration in the oxide and no concentration gradient (Fig. 4)

conditions.atmosphere: high purity $\cdot { < } 1$ ppm impurities including $\mathrm { O } _ { 2 }$ deuterium gas

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: Figure 5 shows typical deuterium concentration profiles in oxides taken from inside surfaces of removed pressure tubes, and from pressure tube material coupons exposed outreactor in autoclaves, in which oxides were considerably thicker than those oxides examined following gaseous exposures.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: The increases in deuterium content found in the outer layers of oxide probably were a result of both surface roughness (in the outermost regions) and deuterium loss during specimen storage in water, implying this outer oxide contains interconnected porosity or cracks.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: the decrease in deuterium contents observed in these profiles just before the metal/oxide interface suggests the presence of a relatively pore-free oxide existing close to the interface, in which the transport of deuterium is controlled by much slower bulk diffusional processes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxide/metal interface formed in steam at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ after $2 4 \ \mathrm { h }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: the oxide consisting of fine equiaxed grains generally ${ < } 1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ diameter may be seen.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxide was highly porous throughout as shown in Figs. $6 b$ and $6 c$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: The pores may be seen to form an interconnected network of up to $1 0 ~ \mathrm { { n m } }$ wide following the equiaxed grain boundaries.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: A specimen of $Z \mathbf { r } – 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ prefilmed out-reactor in steam at $4 0 0 \mathrm { { \circ } _ { C } }$ for 24 h was examined.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk3
evidence_span: the columnar grains of oxide (typically $4 0 \mathrm { n m }$ wide and ${ 2 0 0 } \mathrm { n m }$ long) are related to the substrate orientation.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: Amorphous material, generally ~10 nm thick, was also observed both at the metal/oxide interface and at columnar grain boundaries throughout the oxide.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: Dark field TEM micrograph of a typical region of the oxide formed on Zr-2.5Nb during out-reactor corrosion showing amorphous material at the columnar oxide grain boundaries

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: Thin oxides formed in steam at 400°C on Zr-2.5Nb act as excellent hydrogen permeation barriers following up to 4350 EFPD exposure

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: Diffusivity of deuterium into the oxide inferred from these profiles (~10^-22 m²/s at 300°C)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: values obtained from out-reactor experiments (~10^-21 m²/s at 300°C)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: in-reactor exposures do not reduce (and may improve) the barrier properties of the oxide film

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: inferred values of diffusion coefficient were ~20 times higher than in specimens that were not vacuum annealed

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: TEM of this specimen revealed a network of interconnected pores extending to the interface

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk4
evidence_span: flat deuterium concentration profiles were only observed on pure zirconium with a relatively thick steam-formed oxide

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk5
evidence_span: Assuming that the oxide-metal interface is an absolute barrier and there is no deuterium flux across it, and that the concentration on the oxide surface, $C _ { 0 }$ , is constant

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk5
evidence_span: transfer of deuterium across the interface is assumed to result in 1 ppm/annum in the bulk alloy

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk5
evidence_span: deuterium contained in the oxide would escape into the vacuum of the SIMS during analysis. This would produce a profile in which deuterium is low near the oxide surface

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk5
evidence_span: The features referred to and which may be seen in a number of the micrographs are "pores" given the sense of the Fresnel contrast changes with defocus and the appearance of dark field images some of which indicate (where a pore has broken through both surfaces) that there was no material within them

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk5
evidence_span: Some of the "pores" are however associated with amorphous material (necessarily of lower atomic density than the surrounding material from again the Fresnel contrast)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk5
evidence_span: Interconnection is apparently rare at least in the specimens examined to date

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk5
evidence_span: it is well know that the ion-milling rate varies with material, crystal structure, crystalline orientation. etc. Could it be possible that these pores that you have observed are formed due to different ion-milling rates in that area?
value: varies with material, crystal structure, crystalline orientation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk6
evidence_span: Regions of the $\mathbf { Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ specimen examined to date have shown an amorphous layer at the metal/oxide interface

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk6
evidence_span: the initial black oxide transforms into a grey or tan and later white oxide layer at a thickness of 10 to $1 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ independent of the thermal processing history of the tubing

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk6
evidence_span: At an oxide layer thickness of 60 to $8 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , the oxide may spall

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk6
evidence_span: the inferred diffusivity has been consistently in the same order of magnitude $( { \sim } 2 \times 1 0 ^ { - 2 2 } ~ \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { s } )$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk6
evidence_span: a burnup range of approximately 10 to $4 5 ~ \mathrm { M W d / k g U }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk6
evidence_span: the corrosion performance of Zircaloy-4 cladding is improved by longer and/or higher temperature anneals in the alpha range after the material has been beta quenched

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_045_chunk6
evidence_span: single crystal of silicon can be grown in an epitaxial orientation to a substrate when there is an apparently continuous oxide layer at the interface even when the layer is about 0.5 to $0 . 7 { \mathrm { n m } }$ thick
